body: @ssvinarchuk, @tmgstevens having few test failures after implementing PR comments. Hoping to fix and push the changes soon. Apologies again for the delay. Thank you.
@vegiapparao there was a force push to the trunk whit some git history fix, to be able to merge your change, you need to rebase it on top of the new trunk.

@tmgstevens, all tests pass locally.  But I had to make couple of test configs for the tests to run.  Add `offsets.topic.replication.factor=1`, change the value of `broker.id` from `0` to `-1` in `kafka-server.properties` under `flume-kafka-channel` and `flume-ng-kafka-sink` projects.  With out these changes, the tests fail with a timeout error.

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:2.20.1:test (default-test) on project flume-ng-kafka-sink: There was a timeout or other error in the fork -> [Help 1]

The below error logged in the test reports:
2018-02-16 02:44:21,958 (kafka-request-handler-0) [ERROR - kafka.utils.Logging.error(Logging.scala:101)] [KafkaApi-0] Number of alive brokers '1' does not meet the required replication factor '3' for the offsets topic (configured via 'offsets.topic.replication.factor'). This error can be ignored if the cluster is starting up and not all brokers are up yet.

Is it a known issue?  I haven't committed/pushed config changes.

Apologies for the multiple commits with minor changes.
This would make sense - clearly in the unit tests we're only running a single broker so the offsets topic would only ever have one replica.
@tmgstevens, should I commit the test config changes or leave them as is?  How would the tests run for you?

@adenes thanks for the review!

EnvVarResolverProperties can still work with this, however, I find it better to have it with the same configuration method as the other config filters.

about the module structure:
the API module has to be separated if we would like to save the new custom implementation developers from depending on something they do not need. This is the proper dependency graph in my opinion.

the default implementations are already in a group module.
I have seen much less pain because of too many loosely coupled module than unnecessarily tightly coupled modules. 

If the API and the implementations would be in the same module, it would create the same kind of circular dependency that other implementations already have in the configuration module. Which I would really like to avoid.

@tmgstevens This branch introduces support for flume to use a Kafka client >= 0.10 ?

There is no other way until this is merged?

@ckdarby This is correct. The Kafka API is unstable enough that it's not possible just to drop in a new version. That said, the current (0.9) client will work with 0.10 and 1.0 brokers as I understand. https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Compatibility+Matrix

While the current (0.9) client will work with 0.10 and 1.0 brokers, there are still some caveats described [here](https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#upgrade_10_performance_impact).

Essentially, for any topic of significant throughput, you must either:
- Use the older on-disk message format, and forego some of the features that come with the newer format, **or**
- Use the newer on-disk message format, in which case the newer broker will downconvert the messages on-the-fly to the older format.  If you do this, the broker cannot use zero-copy to write the message directly from disk to NIC, and consequently it is a huge performance impact.
@tmgstevens, still waiting for your advice on the test config changes, should I commit them or not.  I think I have addressed all your comments.  Thanks
Already rebase those commits on trunk branch, and travis ci system have passed. BTW, it seems that `-DskipTests` param makes all test cases skipped. @szaboferee

Hi @vegiapparao - yes please push those changes to your branch.

I'll then take a final look and run through of the tests.
@tmgstevens I will push them and let you know by end of today (NZDT).
@tmgstevens I pushed all the changes.
@tmgstevens did you get chance to look at the changes?
Sorry, I've been away - will try to get to it this week.
hello ？

Hi @szaboferee,
It seems I did not base my change on the right branch. Before I continue let's clarify:
 - should I rebase on flume-1.x or trunk?
 - what is the java version to use.

@szaboferee 
I ran the two tests you mentioned but they did not fail for me. I'm new to Flume so maybe I missed something. Thanks!
@andrasbeni  trunk and 1.8
LGTM, +1
Started testing. Found a problem with packaging: flume-ng-hbase2-sink*.jar is is not added to the distribution package.

New problem found:
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: org.apache.flume.sink.hbase2.HBase2Sink.<init>(java.lang.String)
  at java.lang.Class.getConstructor0(Class.java:3082) ~[?:1.8.0_171]
  at java.lang.Class.getConstructor(Class.java:1825) ~[?:1.8.0_171]
  at org.apache.flume.conf.sink.SinkConfiguration$SinkConfigurationType.getConfiguration(SinkConfiguration.java:190) ~[flume-ng-configuration-1.9.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:1.9.0-SNAPSHOT]

> Found a problem with packaging: flume-ng-hbase2-sink*.jar is is not added to the distribution package.

Fixed. Thanks for catching it.

> java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: org.apache.flume.sink.hbase2.HBase2Sink.

Fixed. It was a copy-paste error in SinkConfiguration. "HBase2Sink" was configured as the configuration class which led to NoSuchMethodException. 
Defining a non-existing (!) class (like in case of HBase sink and many other sinks) won't cause error and the default SinkConfiguration will be initialized.
However, I don't think this is the best solution for SinkConfiguration and all the enum values should be cleaned up in the future.

My manual tests has passed. Here is what I did:
I deployed the flume dist package on a 4 node hadoop cluster running hbase.
Put an appropriate hbase-site.xml in the flume conf directory.
Created a minimal config for the hbase2 sink
a1.sinks.k1.type = hbase2
a1.sinks.k1.table = foo_table
a1.sinks.k1.columnFamily = bar_cf
a1.sinks.k1.serializer = org.apache.flume.sink.hbase2.SimpleHBase2EventSerializer
Created the necessary table and column family in hbase shell.
Used a spooldir for generating events.
Check the hbase table in the hbase shell. Found all the events there.

Hi, I am getting below error when reading logs from rabbitmq server to HDFS path using flume
 
 
 
Exception in thread "PollableSourceRunner-RabbitMQSource-rabbitmq-source1" java.lang.AbstractMethodError: org.apache.flume.source.rabbitmq.RabbitMQSource.getBackOffSleepIncrement()J
at org.apache.flume.source.PollableSourceRunner$PollingRunner.run(PollableSourceRunner.java:142)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)

Hi @zhipcui why do you need this?

These are internal variables and they can be set with different parameters.

What are you trying to achieve?

All these variables can be set by `flume-env.sh` file on conf dir.
Take `JAVA_OPTS ` as example, if I want to change it, I need `flume-env.sh` file.  
Setting this variables from environment variable would be a more clean way especially run the flume using Kubernetes.
retest this please

Hi @lingjinjiang,

Could you please help me to understand the problem this PR solves?
"However, when the syslog format is changed, the "host" header will miss."
Maybe the SyslogParser needs fixing.

Endre

Thanks for your contribution. I have some questions:
Why does it matter if we use HBaseSink?
How could we test this the simplest way?

Thanks,
Endre
